content1.EN:
• As you learned in the previous Module, education records are records that contain [TERM personally identifiable information]the kind of information or data from which the identity of a specific person can be determined.[/TERM].

  • FERPA classifies this information into two categories:

    1. Directory Information

      • Information that is generally not considered harmful or an invasion of privacy if disclosed

      • usually intended to help the campus community thrive

    2. Non-Directory Information

      • Consists of everything else that is contained in student records including:

        • grades

        • transcripts

        • declarations

        • correspondence

        • reports

• FERPA leaves the final decision to each educational institution as to what information will be made publicly available.

  • FERPA provides a list of items that MAY be included in [TERM directory information]Publicly available information not generally considered harmful or an invasion of privacy.[/TERM].

  • What the institution decides to classify as directory information must be published in its [TERM annual notification]a required notification published on an annual basis by the institution that notifies students of their FERPA rights, how to exercise those rights, and what information it classifies as “directory information” which can be shared. You will learn more about the annual notification in Module 7[/TERM].

  • The following MAY NOT be included in directory information:

    • social security number

title.EN: Directory Information - What MAY Be Included

content1.EN:
The following are examples of information that may be classified as "directory information" and can therefore be shared:

  • name

  • address, telephone listing

  • electronic mail address

  • photograph

  • date/place of birth

  • major field of study

  • grade level

  • enrollment status

  • [TERM dates of attendance]refers to a general period of time the student has been attending the institution. Does not mean daily attendance records.[/TERM]

  • degrees, honors, and awards

  • most recent educational institution attended

  • participation in recognized activities and sports

  • weight and height of members of athletic teams

[CASESTUDY Ted Faculty is tired of students asking about their grades after every examination, so he decides to post student grades on the wall outside his office. Is this allowed under FERPA?]In general this is not a good practice, especially since many institutions now have electronic methods for students to privately view their scores. If Ted insists on this practice he is permitted to do so. However, the grades must be posted in such a manner that they are known only to the individual student and the instructor (establishing a secret code, for example). Grades should not be posted in the same order as a class roster or in alphabetical order.[/CASESTUDY]
